title: Rotational KE - rank I and K for 2 spheres

content.question: Two identical spheres <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> are connected to rigid rods of negligible mass, as shown in the figure. The rods-spheres system rotates about point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> with a constant angular velocity. With respect to point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, how do the spheres’ rotational inertias <math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> compare, and how do the spheres’ rotational kinetic energies <math alttext="K sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> compare?

choices.label: <math alttext="I sub X is less than I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub X is less than K sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="I sub X is less than I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub X equals K sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="I sub X equals I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub X is less than K sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="I sub X equals I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub X equals K sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="I sub X is less than I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub X is less than K sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
